I was trying to switch from phpeclipse to PDT and have the problem with _all_ my existing projects. That most of the php-files have an extension .module (drupal modules) probably doesn't help much either, but .php and .inc files suffered the same problem.
Creating a new project with PDT things seem to work fine (haven't yet tested much).
Seems a migration path for users of phpeclipse is needed ...

(In reply to comment #4)
> Creating a new project with PDT things seem to work fine (haven't yet tested
> much).

Did some more testing with strange results:
Opening a .php or .inc file in an old project does open the editor, but the outline is empty.
Creating a .php or .inc file in the new PDT project works as expected. If I call the file something.module the editor crashes (yes, I did associate .module files with the php-editor).

There is no automatic way to migrate PHPEclipse projects to PDT but try this:
1. Create new empty PDT Project.
2. Open .project file.
3. Open .project file of existing PHPEclipse project.
4. Replace Nature & Builders in the .project of existing PHPEclipse project with ones from newly created PDT project.

(In reply to comment #6)
> There is no automatic way to migrate PHPEclipse projects to PDT but try this:

I don't need an automatic migration, that's maybe a nice idea but something I can live without.
But reimporting the php-sources into new projects doesn't completely solve my problem:

For part 1 it seems I'd only have needed a little help-pointer.
I always associated *.module files with the php-editor, but unless one sets the content-type association from *.module file to php, it doesn't really work.

Which means that if I have a php-file that for some reason has an extension not registered with the php content type, the php outline for that won't be filled.

For example, in a drupal-module a have a file called <modulename>.install, which is also a php-file. Now I don't want to associate *.install files with the php content type, but I'd really appreciate it if I could at least open the file with the php-editor instead of having the editor crash ...

this works fine, didn't encounter any problems with editing/opening files for
